course.subject: MARK
course.name: Strategic Marketing
course.description: Developing a comprehensive and integrated framework for directing and managing the marketing functions of a company; methods to analyze marketing opportunities, assess competitive advantages and forecast market changes.
course.prerequisites: MARK 2120, MARK 3220 and MARK 3420

reviews.author: alyssaaa
reviews.title: Heavy workload but good grades!
reviews.comment_content:
The content of this course is not very difficult, just simply read through lecture slides will be sufficient enough for your understanding.

- Quantitative Analysis in Marketing
- Marketing Strategy – What Is It?
- Identifying Target Markets
- Value Proposition & Positioning
- Managing Products
- Managing Prices
- Managing Distribution
- Managing Promotion & Communications
- Understanding Consumers
reviews.comment_teaching: Gene has a good accent which makes it easier for you to understand the course content, and he is pretty timely in answering questions from students as well. Do reach out to Gene and ask him questions regarding the case studies or the PharmaSim simulation game whenever your group has any questions, as sometimes he might give you clearer directions when you seek for comments/ feedback through email or after class whenever you are unsure of some concepts or theories mentioned in class.
reviews.comment_grading:
Grading of this course is pretty fine, my final exam and my group assignments are just slightly above mean but still got B+. Try to answer questions in class if you wish to earn more participation points!

The case studies are not very difficult despite their length, but please make sure your group is in the right direction for every question, else you will get pretty much points deducted.

For the PharmaSim game, your group doesn't necessarily have to score the highest among your class, as long as you write clear explanations in your final report for the simulation game, Gene will still give you points, Again, the explanations should be very clear and detailed - our group got points deducted because of this!
reviews.comment_workload:
Despite the good grade, the workload from this course is heavy - basically you have to meet with your team every week for either PharmaSim or case studies, sometimes both lol. The meetings could be longer if your group needs a lot of discussion on each and every task, for my group there was once we met for like 3 hours. Good thing is, no presentation needed! Just the simulation game and case studies and final report.

Other than having heavy workload on group assignments, the individual part is fine - you just have to work hard for like a week in order to prepare for your final exam, which is just composed of 25 MC questions in my term.

reviews.author: cwyyy
reviews.comment_content:
1. Quantitative Analysis
2. Marketing Strategy
3. Situation Analysis
4. Segmentation, Targeting, Positioning
5. Product
6. Pricing
7. Channel
8. Promotion
9. Viral Marketing

More or less similar to other marketing courses.
Basically talking about 4Ps and STP again, so don't expect to learn something new from this course. The content is quite repetitive and boring imo. But this is a compulsory course for all marketing students.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Gene didn't teach much throughout the semester. Most of the classes in the first-half of the semester is just in-class team discussion on PharmaSim. (Only 9 lecture slides for the entire course) Don't know what I have learnt from this course...
Gene speaks in a pretty slow pace, so it's not to concentrate on his lecture. I usually use review the lectures in 2x speed which is normal to me lol
His own examples are used to illustrate the marketing concepts. He also used pretty much time to explain the cases while we can read them by ourselves.
Before final, he gave us a sample calculation question to familiarize ourselves with the test. He actually simply copied a question from an Accounting textbook WITHOUT realizing the calculation method is DIFFERENT from we have learned in class. My friends and I were very confused so we asked the TA for the solution, but the TA refused to give us lol. Not until I sent email to Gene did we realize the fact (You can tell how much time they have devoted for teaching this course...)
reviews.comment_grading:
Quantitative Analysis Exercise: 10%
Class Participation: 10%
Cases Analyses: 20%
PharmaSim: 25%
Final Exam: 25%
Peer Evaluation: 8%
Research Credit: 2%

All groups got similar marks for the cases analyses. I would say PharmaSim performance and Final Exam determine most of your grade. Do spend adequate time for the cases and PharmaSim. Final is neither extremely challenging or tricky, as long as you review the lecture notes and understand the calculation.
I think the mean is around B (?)
reviews.comment_workload:
Quantitative Analysis Exercise: Easy assignment, just follow the definition and calculation taught in class and you'll be fine. Nothing tricky.

Cases Analyses: Quite a number of cases to be done (5 in total), questions like drafting a marketing plan and discussing the pros and cons of the company's approach. Some calculations are also needed in your reports.

PharmaSim: Try not to finish all 7 rounds at once. Your group discussion can be time-consuming so I suggest you start early and don't be deadline fighters. A report about your learning from PharmaSim should be submitted at the end of the semester (My group ranked quite high at last, we included a lot of marketing concepts that we applied to make us succeed in our report, but Gene gave us a low mark because we were not discussing any mistakes learnt from the game.... I was really confused about what he wants from the report..... like we didn't make any major mistake so that we ranked high right?!)

Final Exam: Gene originally planned to make a close-book exam heavily focused on calculation and essay questions, but then he changed to an all-MC final and allowed us to bring 1 double-sided cheat sheet (I'm immediately relieved). Questions are mainly about definitions and calculations. Just put everything in the lecture slides into my cheat sheet.

Class Participation: No comments for that. We're having online lessons and Gene didn't ask us questions during lectures.

reviews.author: avv
reviews.comment_content:
This is the final marketing course for every MARK student to take. It is mainly about taking marketing strategies after considering various factors such as 4Ps,STPs etc. You are expected to apply the concepts learnt in the previous MARK classes to this one.

For a MARK course, this is the most quantitative in nature as it will involve applying formulas and calculations. It's a bit challenging to adjust to this as most people are used to MARK being more theoretical in nature.  

There will be a bunch of cases to read throughout the semester, some boring as fuck, some kinda interesting. Exam questions are similar to the case questions although the assigned cases would not be tested.

The main project work is playing a simulation game called PharmaSim where the main objective is to achieve the maximum possible stock price for a cold medicine which is the main product for a company. The game can be quite confusing and make no sense at times, so better to get started as soon AS THE TRIAL PERIOD BEGINS. Because after the trial period, any decision you will take will actually contribute to your final score for PharmaSim. The game will be time consuming as you'll need to analyze multiple variables such as price, salesforce, advertising, promotion, special decision etc. and make decisions for each one of them. There will be 2 rounds of PharmaSim in the semester, the best of either round will be taken as the final score. You will be competing with other groups in the class, so pay attention to the comparative results as you play along. Some people nailed this game, some people fucked it up (like my group lol) so you need to play carefully. It is worth taking the professor's advice, ask seniors about the game, use older sources for reference. But there is definitely a luck factor involved in this game, so you can only hope for the best and be able to justify your decisions.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Gene is a cool teacher as he will give interesting examples in class and has a good sense of humor, not afraid to let a few swear words which makes class a bit more lively lol. But some days I'd have to admit he is quite boring. Especially the days he explains the cases, you'd fall asleep. He speaks quite slowly, prob his age, which makes it hard to concentrate at times.

But when it came to the quantitative stuff, I feel he could have done a better job. He did explain the calculations but could have explained better in terms of the logic and where he pulled the numbers from. From what I have heard, the other prof Jiewen Hong explained the quant. stuff quite well so it's worth sitting in both classes and see who is more suitable for you.
reviews.comment_grading:
Midterm 27 %
Final     27 %
Attendance/ Participation 12
PharmaSim                      25
Peer Eval                         7
Research Credit              2

Midterm, Final, PharmaSim are the deciding factors in my opinion. Rest are easy to care of.

It's curved across the 4 classes, so if you get above mean, you should be good.
reviews.comment_workload:
Depends on how you work with your groupmates. For some, weekly meetings for PharmaSim. Some people legit played all 7 rounds for one day which I don't recommend at all. But it is manageable and not too heavy. Apart from that not much.

They expect cases to be read beforehand, but a majority barely read it or didn't even bother to find out about the case. So Gene would just explain it anyways knowing the fact that most wouldn't care to read it. You will need to submit the answers for the case discussed in class a day or 2 day later. This is a group submission so any one person can do it. I guess this is just participation, and they wouldn't bother to check if the answers are actually right or wrong.

There is a PharmaSim report to do at the end of the semester which would be due sometime in the study break, so try to finish it beforehand. Follow the guidelines strictly and what he mentions in class i.e properly justify your decisions and give an example of a quantitative analysis you did to show proof.

reviews.author: linda
reviews.comment_content: A comprehensive marketing course that is like a wrap-up of all the marketing content you've learnt throughout the years. Teaches you to think more like a marketer/businessman and apply the concepts rather than just knowing the theories.
reviews.comment_teaching: Prof. Hong is really engaging and teaches very well. Very interactive teaching style, so you are encouraged to speak up. She teaches in a very clear and logical way with many real-life examples so you can understand the concepts very easily. She is also one of the few profs who really care about their students.
reviews.comment_grading: Grading is curved across all sections (including the other prof's sections). It is fair; just try your best to do well in all components and it will be fine.
reviews.comment_workload: Thankfully there are no big group projects for this course, just a simulation game (PharmaSim) and a report about your group's decisions in the game. However, the simulation game does take up a lot of time if you want to do well. The report is not too tough since it is limited to 4 pages.

reviews.author: WishMeLuck
reviews.title: Apply ur mkt knowledge in a simulation game
reviews.comment_content:
The content of each chapter is easy to understand, which includes positioning, product strategy, pricing, to name but a few. You should have heard of these terms before as this is the last required course in MARK major.

There are several cases, but you don't need to understand very thoroughly as Prof will go through with you and post the model answers on Canvas.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Prof. Hong is a really nice Professor; she encourages all the students to speak up during the lecture. There are 3 casual quizzes held during the lecture, which is not counted into the course grade. The winner of the quiz will get a prize from Prof.

Prof. Hong doesn't allow student to use laptop during the lecture; however, if you forget to print out the cases, she will turn a blind eye to let you read the cases on your laptop.
reviews.comment_grading:
Mid-term Exam 27%
Final Exam 27%
PharmaSim 25%
Class Participation 12%
Peer Evaluation 7%
Research Credit 2%

There are 2 mt and 1 exam. All of them are in case study format and you will need to do some calculation based on the given cases in the exam.  

PharmaSim is the name of the simulation game; you will be in a group of 6-8 to make various marketing decisions for a company on the website. You can expect that PharmaSim will take you the most time for the course. One hint I can provide here is: find some responsible teammates who are good at analyzing data.

I got ~1SD above each quiz but PharmaSim didn't play well. My final grade is B+.
reviews.comment_workload: Not heavy at all. No assignments, only 3 quizzes (include exam). If your team continuously pay efforts in PharmaSim, the workload of this course is really light.
